html: As far as I can tell, this software has never had a proper install target defined for make. Weirdly, it seems to me that the software was designed to be run from the same directory it was compiled in. If it is easier to build and install the software from sources, then the package maintainers of the various distros will make and maintain the packages for you.
text: As far as I can tell, this software has never had a proper install target defined for make. Weirdly, it seems to me that the software was designed to be run from the same directory it was compiled in. If it is easier to build and install the software from sources, then the package maintainers of the various distros will make and maintain the packages for you.

html: I guess what I am saying is that there does not seem to be a guideline as to where the software would like it's files. html: The way I have it set up, the binaries from the engine ends up in /usr/bin,  there is a measure of success there. Both vegastrike and vegasettings support a switch which tells them where the data directory is. The files from the Production-Assets ends up in /usr/share/vegastrike on my system, that is where I would expect game data to be. There are a few config files and icons and so that really don't belong in the game data directory..... Thing is, with a proper install target for make, one can set the install directory, and this is also a variable that can be passed to the binaries at build time, so they would know where to look for the data when it runs. The packagers have a neat trick where they fool the install target to install into a chroot, and so all the files of the game is captured, zipped and ready to install on similar systems. Easy-peasy. I know this part of developing is not that glamarous... so I'll have a crack at where each of the files should be, and feed it back to you guys for comments. From that, we can define an install target for make that makes everybody happy.
text: The way I have it set up, the binaries from the engine ends up in /usr/bin,  there is a measure of success there. Both vegastrike and vegasettings support a switch which tells them where the data directory is. The files from the Production-Assets ends up in /usr/share/vegastrike on my system, that is where I would expect game data to be. There are a few config files and icons and so that really don't belong in the game data directory..... Thing is, with a proper install target for make, one can set the install directory, and this is also a variable that can be passed to the binaries at build time, so they would know where to look for the data when it runs. The packagers have a neat trick where they fool the install target to install into a chroot, and so all the files of the game is captured, zipped and ready to install on similar systems. Easy-peasy. I know this part of developing is not that glamarous... so I'll have a crack at where each of the files should be, and feed it back to you guys for comments. From that, we can define an install target for make that makes everybody happy.

html: I have added a line to each of the CMakelists.txt of vegastrike, vegasettings and mesh_tool, and they now install in a nicely track-able way if you were to run "make install" after running make for the engine. This is of course on my local copy. For the data files no CMakelists.txt exists, and of course it's not compiled, it's just data that needs to go live somewhere in a filesystem. Whether that is /opt/vegastrike, or /usr/share/vegastrike or /usr/local/share/vegastrike needs to be settable to make everyone happy.

text: @BenjamenMeyer The way I have it set up at the moment is that the engine requires the data, ie: completely opposite your suggestion. It is not carved in stone, and I can switch it around without the world coming apart. The more I think about it, your approach makes more sense.

html: I am now in the process of making a new "vegastrike-git" package, which will provide the data, and require vegastrike-engine to be installed. In the future, one could conceivably have a privateer-remake package that also requires the vegastrike-engine package. This way both packages can be installed concurrently, and use the same engine
text: I am now in the process of making a new "vegastrike-git" package, which will provide the data, and require vegastrike-engine to be installed. html: @BenjamenMeyer I have completed the old switcheroo on the packages. Now in AUR, vegastrike-git provides the data files, and vegastrike-engine-git provides the engine. I went against having a vegastrike-data providing the data, as something needs to provide "vegastrike" to the system. In this way, installing "vegastrike" also installs it's engine. It may be conceivable that if the engine wants to be multiple-use, we can call it something different, then have a wrapper in the data package (installed to bin) that call it with the proper location of the data it's supposed to be operating on.
text: @BenjamenMeyer I have completed the old switcheroo on the packages. Now in AUR, vegastrike-git provides the data files, and vegastrike-engine-git provides the engine. I went against having a vegastrike-data providing the data, as _something_ needs to provide "vegastrike" to the system. In this way, installing "vegastrike" also installs it's engine. It may be conceivable that if the engine wants to be multiple-use, we can call it something different, then have a wrapper in the data package (installed to bin) that call it with the proper location of the data it's supposed to be operating on.

html: @Loki1950 if there is no development going to happen in Assets-Production, why have it as a git repo at all? The same purpose can be achieved by hosting a tarball pulled from master at a good time. It makes for a smaller (resumable) download, simpler packaging and provides a stable base to build the engine against. At the moment the vegastrike-git package in AUR uses the Assets-Production git repository, as that was what was what was suggested in the install instructions. Changing it over to Assets-Master is easy enough to do, but involves pulling a rather large git repo.
text: @Loki1950 if there is no development going to happen in Assets-Production, why have it as a git repo at all? The same purpose can be achieved by hosting a tarball pulled from master at a good time. It makes for a smaller (resumable) download, simpler packaging and provides a stable base to build the engine against. At the moment the vegastrike-git package in AUR uses the Assets-Production git repository, as that was what was what was suggested in the install instructions. Changing it over to Assets-Master is easy enough to do, but involves pulling a rather large git repo.

html: @BenjamenMeyer, please, if you don't mind. I promise I won't shower you with any more files. The CMakeLists.txt, and the two wrapper files 'vs' and 'vsettings' into Assets-Production. The wrapper files frees one up from running vegastrike and vegasettings in the data directory only. The CMakeLists.txt installs all the common data and the Linux-specific .desktop and icons files to their correct places. The CMakeLists.txt respects the DESTDIR variables, and defaults to the more common /usr/local, as do the wrapper scripts. I was a little bored today, and I don't know enough about coding to fix that SPEC jumping bug

html: @BenjamenMeyer yes, the vs and vsettings go with the assets. The theory here is that they call the engine with the settings to find the data directory. As such, they are system agnostic, and belong with the data. Looking forward, should I package Gemini Gold or some such thing, one could make wrapper scripts for that game to also use the installed vegastrike engine.
text: @BenjamenMeyer yes, the vs and vsettings go with the assets. The theory here is that they call the engine with the settings to find the data directory. As such, they are system agnostic, and belong with the data. Looking forward, should I package Gemini Gold or some such thing, one could make wrapper scripts for that game to also use the installed vegastrike engine.
